answers.answer: In some people the sinus node dysfunction may result in alternating slow and fast heart rates (bradycardia-tachycardia syndrome). The medication for high blood pressure may keep the high bp within a normal range.  An underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism) or overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism) can cause low blood pressure. There can be an electroytic imbalance due to diet, etc. In addition, other conditions, such as adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease), low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) and, in some cases, diabetes, can trigger low blood pressure.You may want to contact the doctor's office for advise whether you should be immediately treated or have an evaluation at a later date.  Take care and thanks for sharing and if you have any follow-up questions you are welcome to ask.

question: I've had diabetes for 55 years; heart by-pass surgery 18 years ago and have been on multiple hbp meds for as many years.  Recently, have been having episodes of low bp.  My drs have gradually taken me off all bp meds but I continue to have low bp (80/44 this am and it's been lower than that many times) when I wake---afternoon and evenings are around 110/60.  I passed out once and felt faint many times.  I lost 30 pounds last year(spouse on diet)-now weigh 134 lbs and am 5'7" .  My bp readings at drs offices are always elevated; I know bp is low at home as I feel so bad, weak,tired I can hardly walk across the floor so check bp and it's low. Annual apt with cardiologist in 3 weeks.  Do I just continue to wait until appt or should I try to get in earlier?
title: Had HBP now it's LBP
